title: Barbara Kingsolver is a genius.
content: BARBARA KINGSOLVER sets her version of DAVID COPPERFIELD in the Appalachians. The original version dealt with the mistreatment of poor youngsters in Victorian England. Dickens wrote from experience. Kingsolver sets her sites on orphans and the abuses of the foster parent system. Demon has a drug addicted mother who marries a man who believes Demon needs discipline, physical discipline. When his mother dies, a social worker decides Demon would be better off in the foster system. Heâ€™s abused again by an old farmer who works him and his fellow fosters almost to death, but he meets a life-long friend in Tommy who will help him find a career. One of the other kids on the farm is the star football player for the Generals. Demon worships him only to find out later he has feet of clay.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: His next family has a bunch of other kids, which means Demon doesnâ€™t get enough to eat. He runs away to try to find his grandmother. When he finds her, she learns he hasnâ€™t been going to school, and she puts him with the coach of the Generals. Thatâ€™s where he meets another character, Angus (Agnes) the coachâ€™s daughter who will become another lifelong protector. Demon is around twelve when he goes to live with the coach; the coach sees some athletic prowess in Demon who will ultimately become the tight end on the Generals. Thatâ€™s where he hurts his knee. A doctor gives him opiates for the pain, leading to a spiral toward drug addiction.

title: Verified Purchase
content: Like everyone says, this is a beautifully written, insightful book about the Southern Appalachians and people who inhabit those beautiful hills. You should definitely read it. But I had to take off a star (well, half a star) because Kingsolver managed to stuff every trope about the region between its covers like it was a J.D. Vance stump speech to a Dukes of Hazzard convention.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2024

title: Amazing but also a lot
content: Amazing book, really did our region of the world great justice, but if youâ€™re from here, you know what Iâ€™m taking about: football, guns, opioids, a Black teacher watching kids fly the Confederate flag, teen pregnancy, a teen mom killed in a drag racing incident, a teen mom killed by OxyContinâ€¦ I mean, the main character is literally Melungeon. Sure, the stereotypes are all true, but do they all have to be in the same 450 pages? Kingsolver gets so mad at a pseudonymous Snuffy Smith for perpetuating lazy hillbilly stereotypes, and a few pages later runs into Dolly Parton at a Nashville grocery store buying a humble head of lettuce.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2024

post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2024

title: Moving, funny, unstoppably absorbing
content: DEMON COPPERHEAD delighted, engaged, educated, depressed and hooked me beyond all my expectations. I was especially open to learning about this part of America because I recently spent a week near Roanoke VA at a family wedding. I saw nothing on that trip of the world in this book except the good parts of Virginia that the protagonist sold me on. I was already offended on behalf of Appalachia in terms of how most media deride its citizens and mock them. Now I feel a kinship. Beyond that I feel inspired to read outstanding and engaging fiction again â€” and, as a somewhat lapsed fiction writer, inspired to write it. I cried; I was moved and surprised and also vindicated by plot twists Iâ€™d hope would play out. I laughed and had my mind opened. A deeply real and life-affirming journey. My first Kingsolver but not my last!
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: Demon Copperhead by Barbara Kingsolver is a long novel with strong messages, as are many of her books. Told from the perspective, and in the voice of, a boy named Demon Copperhead, the reader accompanies him from his birth to a single mother without a penny to her name, his abuse at the hands of his stepfather and during his stays in multiple foster homes, his teenaged years as a star football player, his first love, his drug addiction and recovery and finally his tentative start on a new journey.

title: Verified Purchase
content: Barbara Kingsolver has put on a showcase with both her love and sadness for her beloved Appalachia. She did this brilliantly with the creation of the fabulous and memorable Demon Copperhead. I love first person narrators and Demon is one of the very best. His voice makes this novel. With his ironic wit Demon narrates the story of his life from birth to adulthood. We learn that he was born to a teenage single mother, who was addicted to alcohol and drugs. They lived in a small community in the Southern Appalachians.  Here come disappointmentsâ€¦He becomes an orphan and we see his experience after this, including terrible foster homes. Some good things happen to Demon as well. His life is a rollercoaster, with many nauseating highs and lows. Speaking of highs and lows, he gets the physical kind as well when he joins the excess of painkiller addicts in his community.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2024
